none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Thos. R. Laughin (), April 13, 1886
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Thos. R. Laughin (), April 13, 1886
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 22 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value: Ho Apr 13 1886 Mr. L. L. McInnis Dear Sir We send you by express the trunk ordered price $13.75. In the letter pocket of the trunk you will find $3500 in money please credit Cadet Foster with 3000 amount due college & hand the balance 500 to Foster. We have also taken the liberty to put in a small pk which we will be obliged if you will hand him Respt Thos G. Franklin F.

**Image Analysis and Transcription: A Detailed Walkthrough** Okay, here's the deal. I'm looking at this image of a handwritten letter, and my goal is to produce a clean, accurate transcription. As an expert, I'm going to take a methodical approach, and here's my thought process: First things first: the date. Top right corner. I'm seeing "Ho Apr 13 1886". Or maybe "St L"? The first letter is a bit tricky, but given the context of the addressee (L.L. McInnis at Texas A&M) and the year (1886), a location like Houston or St. Louis are possible. Let's dig deeper. The "H" is distinctive. Looks like it has a loop. It looks less like the "S" in "Sir". Let's stick with "Ho" or "St L". Let's assume Houston. Now, the addressee. It's clearly "Mr L L McInnis". The handwriting's pretty neat, cursive, easy to make out. "Mr. L. L. McInnis". The salutation is simple: "Dear Sir". That's a gimme. The body of the letter is where things get interesting. I'll take it line by line: * "We send you" - Clear. * "by express the trunk ordered" - Also clear. * "price $13.75. In the letter pocket" - Right, trunk price and setup. The amount looks accurate. Period after the price is there. * "of the trunk you will find $3500" - Ah, now we're getting to the crux. The figure is messy. Is it $36.25? No. It's $35.00. The math will support this. The 3 and 5 are connected in handwriting. A bit of ink. Superscript. * "in money ~~which~~ please credit" - Right. The word "which" is crossed out. So, as a professional, I'll transcribe "in money please credit". * "Cadet Foster with 3000 amount" - Cadet Foster, right. Looks like $30.00. That's good. Superscript. * "due college & hand the balance" - Clear. Ampersand. * "500 to Foster. We have also taken" - Okay, $5.00 to Foster. The numbers align, supporting $35.00 total. Superscript again. * "the liberty to put in a small" - "to put" written as two words. * "pk which we will be obliged" - "pk" is shorthand for "package". The word "which" is legible but unnecessary. * "if you will hand him" - Simple. Closing: "Respt" (Respectfully). Signature: "Thos G. Franklin" - Middle initial looks like a 'G', with that cursive loop underneath. Last name "Franklin". Initial "F" underneath. Let's refine the location. It looks like "Ho" in the header. Or possibly "St L". Let's make "Ho". Now, let's look at formatting. Date at the top right. Left-align the salutation. Paragraphs, indentation for the signature. Let's look at the HTML tags. I'll use paragraph tags (`

`) for structure, line breaks (`
`) where needed, and the superscript tag (``) for the cent signs in dollar amounts. We do not have the ability to use the strike-through tag, therefore, I will omit the crossed-out word "which". Now I am going to assemble the final transcription: Here is the Final transcription: ```html

Ho Apr 13 1886

Mr. L. L. McInnis
    Dear Sir

We send you
by express the trunk ordered
price $13.75. In the letter pocket
of the trunk you will find $3500
in money please credit
Cadet Foster with 3000 amount
due college & hand the balance
500 to Foster. We have also taken
the liberty to put in a small
pk which we will be obliged
if you will hand him
